items.title: Lyon feels 'filthy' after rare Test omission
items.summary: Nathan Lyon is left out of an Australia side for the first time in a home Test since 2012, while the hosts were also still without captain Pat Cummins for the second Ashes Test.

items.title: Root's first ton in Australia keeps England afloat

items.title: The NPU in your phone keeps improvingâ€”why isnâ€™t that making AI better?
items.summary: Shrinking AI for your phone is no simple matter.
items.body: Almost every technological innovation of the past several years has been laser-focused on one thing: generative AI. Many of these supposedly revolutionary systems run on big, expensive servers in a data center somewhere, but at the same time, chipmakers are crowing about the power of the neural processing units (NPU) they have brought to consumer devices. Every few months, itâ€™s the same thing: This new NPU is 30 or 40 percent faster than the last one. Thatâ€™s supposed to let you do something important, but no one really gets around to explaining what that is. Experts envision a future of secure, personal AI tools with on-device intelligence, but does that match the reality of the AI boom? AI on the â€œedgeâ€ sounds great, but almost every AI tool of consequence is running in the cloud. So whatâ€™s that chip in your phone even doing? What is an NPU? Companies launching a new product often get bogged down in superlatives and vague marketing speak, so they do a poor job of explaining technical details. Itâ€™s not clear to most people buying a phone why they need the hardware to run AI workloads, and the supposed benefits are largely theoretical. Read full article Comments

items.title: A fentanyl vaccine is about to get its first major test
items.summary: Vaccine trial in the Netherlands hopes to protect against fentanyl-related overdose and death.
items.body: Just a tiny amount of fentanyl, the equivalent of a few grains of sand, is enough to stop a personâ€™s breathing. The synthetic opioid is tasteless, odorless, and invisible when mixed with other substances, and drug users are often unaware of its presence. Itâ€™s why biotech entrepreneur Collin Gage is aiming to protect people against the drugâ€™s lethal effects. In 2023, he became the cofounder and CEO of ARMR Sciences to develop a vaccine against fentanyl. Now, the company is launching a trial to test its vaccine in people for the first time. The goal: prevent deaths from overdose. â€œIt became very apparent to me that as I assessed the treatment landscape, everything that exists is reactionary,â€ Gage says. â€œI thought, why are we not preventing this?â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Proton Sheets joins the company's productivity suite
items.summary: The latest addition to Proton's workplace suite is a spreadsheet tool called Proton Sheets. It will offer real-time collaboration, and users can control who has access to view and edit files. Proton Sheets can also be accessed on any device, including mobile ones. It supports importing CSV and XLS â€¦

items.title: 'Superb piece of fielding!' - Stokes run out by Inglis
items.summary: England captain Ben Stokes is run out for 19 after a mix-up with Joe Root as the tourists fall to 210-5 on day one of the second Ashes Test against Australia in Brisbane.

items.title: Can anyone stop Lampard's Coventry winning the Championship?
items.summary: Frank Lampard's Coventry City are 10 points clear at the top of the Championship and could create history - but will anything stand in their way?

items.title: The 29 best PC games you can play right now for 2025
items.summary: PC gamers have almost too many options when it comes to titles to play, which is a great problem to have. With decades of games to choose from (and the first port of call for most indie titles, too), the options are endless. You also get the perks of (nearly always flawless) backward compatibility â€¦

items.title: Meta's Oversight Board wants to expand its powers in 2026

Up to now, users have been able to appeal content moderation decisions related to specific posts to the board, but haven't been able to ask the group to intervene in other situations that affect their â€¦

items.title: 'Gifted Australia a wicket' - Vaughan baffled by Brook dismissal
items.summary: Former England captain Michael Vaughan is left dismayed as Harry Brook is caught for 31 by Steve Smith off the bowling of Mitchell Starc as England fall to 176-4 on the opening day of the second Ashes Test in Brisbane.

items.title: British athletes given AI app as shield from online abuse
items.summary: British Olympic and Paralympic athletes are to be offered a new form of artificial intelligence-based protection from online abuse.

items.title: 'Excitement and nerves' for Archibald as Games loom
items.summary: Katie Archibald has already competed in a Commonwealth Games in Glasgow and is eager to do so again next summer.

items.title: Crawley falls for 76 as Australia make key breakthrough after lunch
items.summary: Zak Crawley is caught for 76 off the bowling of Michael Neser, ending a 117-run partnership with Joe Root to leave England on 122-3 on day one of the second Ashes Test in Brisbane.

items.title: 12 former FDA chiefs unite to say agency memo on vaccines is deeply stupid
items.summary: Prasad's arguments "misrepresent both the science and the regulatory record."
items.body: On Friday, Vinay Prasadâ€”the Food and Drug Administrationâ€™s chief medical and scientific officer and its top vaccine regulatorâ€”emailed a stunning memo to staff that quickly leaked to the press. Without evidence, Prasad claimed COVID-19 vaccines have killed 10 children in the US, and, as such, he announced unilateral, sweeping changes to the way the agency regulates and approves vaccines, including seasonal flu shots. On Wednesday evening, a dozen former FDA commissioners, who collectively oversaw the agency for more than 35 years, responded to the memo with a scathing rebuke . Uniting to publish their response in the New England Journal of Medicine, the former commissioners said they were â€œdeeply concernedâ€ by Prasadâ€™s memo, which they framed as a â€œthreatâ€ to the FDAâ€™s work and a danger to Americansâ€™ health. In his memo, Prasad called for abandoning the FDAâ€™s current framework for updating seasonal flu shots and other vaccines, such as those for COVID-19. Those updates currently involve studies that measure well-characterized immune responses (called immunobridging studies). Prasad dismissed this approach as insufficient and, instead, plans to require expensive randomized trials, wâ€¦

items.title: Admins and defenders gird themselves against maximum-severity server vuln
items.summary: Open source React executes malicious code with malformed HTMLâ€”no authentication needed.
items.body: Security defenders are girding themselves in response to the disclosure of a maximum-severity vulnerability disclosed Wednesday in React Server, an open-source package thatâ€™s widely used by websites and in cloud environments. The vulnerability is easy to exploit and allows hackers to execute malicious code on servers that run it. Exploit code is now publicly available . React is embedded into web apps running on servers so that remote devices render JavaScript and content more quickly and with fewer resources required. React is used by an estimated 6 percent of all websites and 39 percent of cloud environments. When end users reload a page, React allows servers to re-render only parts that have changed, a feature that drastically speeds up performance and lowers the computing resources required by the server. Read full article Comments

items.body: BMW provided flights from Washington, DC, to Malaga, Spain, and accommodation so Ars could drive the iX3. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. The new BMW iX3 is an important car for the automaker. Itâ€™s the first of a new series of vehicles that BMW is calling the Neue Klasse, calling back to a range of cars that helped define the brand in the 1960s. Then, as now, propulsion is provided by the best powertrain BMWâ€™s engineers could design and build, wrapped in styling that heralds the companyâ€™s new look. Except now, that powertrain is fully electric, and the cabin features technology that would have been scarcely believable to the driver of a new 1962 BMW 1500. In fact, the iX3 is only half the story when it comes to BMWâ€™s neue look for the Neue Klasseâ€”thereâ€™s an all-electric 3 series sedan on the way, too. The sedan will surely appeal to enthusiasts, particularly the version that the M tuning arm has worked its magic upon, but youâ€™ll have to wait until early 2026 to read about that stuff. Which makes sense: crossovers and SUVsâ€”or â€œsports activity vehiclesâ€ in BMW-speakâ€”are what the market wants these days, so thatâ€™s what comes first. The technical stuff As we learned earlieâ€¦

items.title: Republicans drop Trump-ordered block on state AI laws from defense bill
items.summary: â€œWidespread and powerful movementâ€ keeps Trump from blocking state AI laws.
items.body: A Donald Trump-backed push has failed to wedge a federal measure that would block states from passing AI laws for a decade into the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA). House Majority Leader Steve Scalise (R-La.) told reporters Tuesday that a sect of Republicans is now â€œlooking at other placesâ€ to potentially pass the measure. Other Republicans opposed including the AI preemption in the defense bill, The Hill reported , joining critics who see value in allowing states to quickly regulate AI risks as they arise. For months, Trump has pressured the Republican-led Congress to block state AI laws that the president claims could bog down innovation as AI firms waste time and resources complying with a patchwork of state laws. But Republicans have continually failed to unite behind Trumpâ€™s command, first voting against including a similar measure in the â€œBig Beautifulâ€ budget bill and then this week failing to negotiate a solution to pass the NDAA measure. Read full article Comments

items.title: Humans in southern Africa were an isolated population until recently
items.summary: A distinct population that was isolated until the last thousand years or so.
items.body: The fossil and genetic evidence agree that modern humans originated in Africa. The most genetically diverse human populationsâ€”the groups that have had the longest time to pick up novel mutationsâ€”live there today. But the history of what went on within Africa between our origins and the present day is a bit murky. Thatâ€™s partly because DNA doesnâ€™t survive long in the conditions typical of most of the continent, which has largely limited us to trying to reconstruct the past using data from present-day populations. The other part is that many of those present-day populations have been impacted by the vast genetic churn caused by the Bantu expansion , which left its traces across most of the populations south of the Sahara. But a new study has managed to extract genomes from ancient samples in southern Africa. While all of these are relatively recent, dating from after the end of the most recent glacial period, they reveal a distinct southern African population that was relatively large, outside of the range of previously described human variation, and it remained isolated until only about 1,000 years ago. Read full article Comments

items.title: After nearly 30 years, Crucial will stop selling RAM to consumers
items.summary: Micron cites AI data center demand as reason for killing DIY upgrade brand.
items.body: On Wednesday, Micron Technology announced it will exit the consumer RAM business in 2026, ending 29 years of selling RAM and SSDs to PC builders and enthusiasts under the Crucial brand. The company cited heavy demand from AI data centers as the reason for abandoning its consumer brand, a move that will remove one of the most recognizable names in the do-it-yourself PC upgrade market. â€œThe AI-driven growth in the data center has led to a surge in demand for memory and storage,â€ Sumit Sadana, EVP and chief business officer at Micron Technology, said in a statement. â€œMicron has made the difficult decision to exit the Crucial consumer business in order to improve supply and support for our larger, strategic customers in faster-growing segments.â€ Micron said it will continue shipping Crucial consumer products through the end of its fiscal second quarter in February 2026 and will honor warranties on existing products. The company will continue selling Micron-branded enterprise products to commercial customers and plans to redeploy affected employees to other positions within the company. Read full article Comments

items.title: Rare win for renewable energy: Trump admin funds geothermal network expansion
items.summary: A first-in-the-nation heating and cooling network in Massachusetts is set to double in size.
items.body: The US Department of Energy has approved an $8.6 million grant that will allow the nationâ€™s first utility-led geothermal heating and cooling network to double in size. Gas and electric utility Eversource Energy completed the first phase of its geothermal network in Framingham, Massachusetts, in 2024 . Eversource is a co-recipient of the award along with the city of Framingham and HEET, a Boston-based nonprofit that focuses on geothermal energy and is the lead recipient of the funding. Geothermal networks are widely considered among the most energy-efficient ways to heat and cool buildings. The federal money will allow Eversource to add approximately 140 new customers to the Framingham network and fund research to monitor the systemâ€™s performance. Read full article Comments

items.title: Microsoft drops AI sales targets in half after salespeople miss their quotas
items.summary: Report: Microsoft declared "the era of AI agents" in May, but enterprise customers aren't buying.
items.body: Microsoft has lowered sales growth targets for its AI agent products after many salespeople missed their quotas in the fiscal year ending in June, according to a report Wednesday from The Information. The adjustment is reportedly unusual for Microsoft, and it comes after the company missed a number of ambitious sales goals for its AI offerings. AI agents are specialized implementations of AI language models designed to perform multistep tasks autonomously rather than simply responding to single prompts. So-called â€œagenticâ€ features have been central to Microsoftâ€™s 2025 sales pitch: At its Build conference in May, the company declared that it has entered â€œthe era of AI agents.â€ The company has promised customers that agents could automate complex tasks, such as generating dashboards from sales data or writing customer reports. At its Ignite conference in November, Microsoft announced new features like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint agents in Microsoft 365 Copilot, along with tools for building and deploying agents through Azure AI Foundry and Copilot Studio. But as the year draws to a close, that promise has proven harder to deliver than the company expected. Read full article Comments

items.title: Prime Video pulls eerily emotionless AI-generated anime dubs after complaints

items.body: Amazon Prime Video has scaled back an experiment that created laughable anime dubs with generative AI. In March, Amazon announced that its streaming service would start including â€œAI-aided dubbing on licensed movies and series that would not have been dubbed otherwise.â€ In late November, some AI-generated English and Spanish dubs of anime popped up, including dubs for the Banana Fish series and the movie No Game No Life: Zero . The dubs appear to be part of a beta launch, and users have been able to select â€œEnglish (AI beta)â€ or â€œSpanish (AI beta)â€ as an audio language option in supported titles. â€œAbsolutely disrespectfulâ€ Not everyone likes dubbed content. Some people insist on watching movies and shows in their original language to experience the media more authentically, with the passion and talent of the original actors. But you donâ€™t need to be against dubs to see whatâ€™s wrong with the ones Prime Video tested. Read full article Comments

items.title: Fraudulent gambling network may actually be something more nefarious
items.summary: Researchers say there's more to the network, which has operated for 14 years.
items.body: A sprawling infrastructure that has been bilking unsuspecting people through fraudulent gambling websites for 14 years is likely a dual operation run by a nation-state-sponsored group that is targeting government and private-industry organizations in the US and Europe, researchers said Wednesday. Researchers have previously tracked smaller pieces of the enormous infrastructure. Last month, security firm Sucuri reported that the operation seeks out and compromises poorly configured websites running the WordPress CMS. Imperva in January said the attackers also scan for and exploit web apps built with the PHP programming language that have existing webshells or vulnerabilities. Once the weaknesses are exploited, the attackers install a GSocket, a backdoor that the attackers use to compromise servers and host gambling web content on them. All of the gambling sites target Indonesian-speaking visitors. Because Indonesian law prohibits gambling, many people in that country are drawn to illicit services. Most of the 236,433 attacker-owned domains hosting the gambling sites are hosted on Cloudflare. Most of the 1,481 hijacked subdomains were hosted on Amazon Web Services, Azure, and GitHubâ€¦

items.title: Planned satellite constellations may swamp future orbiting telescopes
items.summary: Planned orbital observatories would see satellites cross nearly all of their images.
items.body: On Wednesday, three NASA astronomers released an analysis showing that several planned orbital telescopes would see their images criss-crossed by planned satellite constellations, such as a fully expanded Starlink and its competitors. While the impact of these constellations on ground-based has been widely considered, orbital hardware was thought to be relatively immune from their interference. But the planned expansion of constellations, coupled with some of the features of upcoming missions, will mean that at least one proposed observatory will see an average of nearly 100 satellite tracks in every exposure. Making matters worse, some of the planned measures meant to minimize the impact on ground-based telescopes will make things worse for those in orbit. Constellations vs. astronomy Satellite constellations are a relatively new threat to astronomy; prior to the drop in launch costs driven by SpaceXâ€™s reusable rockets, the largest constellations in orbit consisted of a few dozen satellites. But the rapid growth of the Starlink system caused problems for ground-based astronomy that are not easy to solve . Read full article Comments

items.title: Guitar amp sims have gotten astonishingly good
items.summary: There has never been a better time to be a guitarist.
items.body: Itâ€™s an incredible time to be a guitarist who doesnâ€™t want to own a bunch of $2,000 amps and an expensive pedalboard of gear. Amp and pedal simulators, which have been around for decades, have in the last few years finally come into their own as nearly indistinguishable sonic replacements. Even John Mayer is now willing to ditch his beloved tube amps for digital models . I certainly donâ€™t have Mayerâ€™s chops or gear budget, but I do love messing with this sort of tech and have purchased everything from NeuralDSP â€˜s Archetypes series to Amplitube and Guitar Rig . Last week, as part of an early Black Friday sale, I picked up two amp/effects suites from British developer Polychrome DSPâ€” Nunchuck (Marshall amps) and Lumos (clean through mid-gain tones). They are both excellent. Any reasonable person should be satisfied with this tech stack, which models gear that collectively costs as much as my house. After my Polychrome DSP purchases, I reminded myself that I am a reasonable person, and that I could therefore ignore any further amp sims that might tempt my wandering eye. Read full article Comments

items.title: More FDA drama: Top drug regulator calls it quits after 3 weeks
items.summary: The last Trump official in the position left amid allegations of petty revenge.
items.body: The top drug regulator at the Food and Drug Administration, Richard Pazdur, has decided to retire from the agency just three weeks after taking the leading position, according to multiple media outlets. Pazdur, an oncologist who has worked at the FDA since 1999, was seen as a stabilizing force for an agency that has been mired in turmoil during the second Trump administration. He took over the role of leading the FDAâ€™s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research on November 11, after the previous leader, George Tidmarsh, left the agency amid an investigation and a lawsuit regarding allegations that he used his position to exact petty revenge on a former business partner. In light of the scandal, one venture capital investor called the agency a â€œ clown show .â€ Drug industry groups, meanwhile, called the FDA erratic and unpredictable . Pazdurâ€™s selection was seen as a positive sign by agency insiders, drug industry representatives, and patient advocacy groups, according to reporting by The Washington Post . Read full article Comments

items.title: Tap to Pay on iPhone hits 50 countries as it launches in Singapore
items.summary: Appleâ€™s Tap to Pay on iPhone is intended to offer the ultimate in convenience and affordability for small businesses looking to accept contactless payment from both mobile wallets and physical cards. The feature is today continuing its global rollout, with Singapore the latest country to get the teâ€¦

items.title: Can viral relationship tests really tell you about your relationship?
items.summary: Is there any science to viral relationship tests like the bird test, the orange peel theory and the moon phase test? Emily Impett, a professor of psychological and brain sciences at the University of Toronto, has the answers

items.title: As Apple reboots its AI work, OpenAI ramps up the pressure by declaring â€˜code redâ€™
items.summary: As Apple loses its AI head and reboots its work with a restructure, OpenAI is ramping up the pressure by declaring â€œcode red.â€ Concerned about being overtaken by Googleâ€™s Gemini, CEO Sam Altman has said that all of the companyâ€™s efforts will be devoted to improving the quality of ChatGPT â€¦ moreâ€¦

items.title: This cute $50 case makes your M4 Mac mini look like a Mac Pro
items.summary: Buying a Mac Pro makes absolutely no sense at the moment given that the Mac Studio is more powerful while also being substantially cheaper. But if you secretly lust after one anyway, then a cute $50 case can make an M4 Mac Mini look just like a miniature Mac Pro â€“ with a couple of practical benefitâ€¦

items.title: Origin story of domestic cats rewritten by genetic analysis
items.summary: Domestic cats originated in North Africa and spread to Europe in the past 2000 years, according to DNA evidence, while in China a different species of cat lived alongside people much earlier

items.title: Physicists have worked out a universal law for how objects shatter
items.summary: Whether it is a cube of sugar or a chunk of a mineral, a mathematical analysis can identify how many fragments of each size any brittle object will break into

items.title: Emergency response needed to prevent climate breakdown, warn experts
items.summary: Scientists sounded the alarm on the dire consequences of continued inaction at a briefing in London, warning that we could be heading for "unprecedented societal and ecological collapse"

items.title: Warming and droughts led to collapse of the Indus Valley Civilisation
items.summary: Hotter temperatures and a series of droughts in what is now Pakistan and India fragmented one of the worldâ€™s major early civilisations, providing a "warning shot" for today

items.title: Deadly fungus makes sick frogs jump far, possibly to find mates
items.summary: Chytrid fungus is a scourge to global amphibian populations, but before it kills some frogs, it can produce symptoms that may help the infected animals find mates and spread the fungus further

items.title: Monthly injection could replace daily steroid pills for severe asthma
items.summary: Daily steroid pills are often necessary for severe cases of asthma, but they raise the risk of several serious conditions. Now, scientists have shown that a monthly antibody injection can eliminate the need for the pills

items.title: Easter Island statues may have been built by small independent groups
items.summary: Mapping of the main quarry on Easter Island where giant statues were carved has uncovered evidence that the monuments may not have been created under the direction of a single chief

items.title: The 12 best science fiction books of 2025
items.summary: From drowned worlds to virtual utopias via deep space, wild ideas abound in Emily H. Wilson's picks for her favourite sci-fi reads of the year

items.title: COP30: The UN climate summits are no longer fit for purpose
items.summary: The final COP30 agreement fails to even mention fossil fuels. Countries wanting to tackle climate change must not wait for the next meeting to take action

items.title: The quick and easy ways to stay fit this holiday season
items.summary: A chaotic schedule over the holiday season often derails Grace Wadeâ€™s workout routine. But this year she has a planâ€¦

items.title: Why dark matter is still one of the biggest open problems in science
items.summary: We can't see dark matter directly, so studying it pushes the boundaries of our creativity as scientists. How exciting, says Chanda Prescod-Weinstein

items.title: Why memory manipulation could be one of humanity's healthiest ideas
items.summary: It might sound like dystopian science fiction, but discovering how to reshape memories responsibly is helping us to heal the brain from within, says Steve Ramirez

items.title: The 13 best popular science books of 2025
items.summary: Women's hidden extra work, positive tipping points and new thinking on autism â€“ there's much to chew on in this year's best reads, says Liz Else

items.title: The science of swimming trunks â€“ including tightness analysis
items.summary: Feedback dives into a new piece of research on the merits of swimming briefs or looser swimming shorts â€“ and raises an eyebrow at its conclusion

items.title: Pandas use tools to scratch thanks to a strange evolutionary quirk
items.summary: Captive giant pandas have been seen breaking off twigs and bamboo pieces to scratch hard-to-reach spots, using a crude opposable thumb that other bears donâ€™t have

items.title: A revolutionary way to map our bodies is helping cure deadly diseases
items.summary: New tools that create ultra-precise maps of our tissues are transforming our ability to diagnose and cure once-fatal illnesses

items.title: Ancient human foot bones shed light on how two species coexisted
items.summary: Scientists have finally assigned foot bones found in 2009 to an ancient human species, and the move suggests that different types of hominins lived close by in harmony

items.title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
items.summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.

items.title: We might have just seen the first hints of dark matter
items.summary: Unexplained gamma ray radiation coming from the edge of the Milky Way galaxy could be produced by self-annihilating dark matter particles â€“ but the idea requires further investigation

items.title: We may need a fourth law of thermodynamics for living systems
items.summary: The laws of thermodynamics don't accurately account for the complex processes in living cells â€“ do we need a new one to accurately measure the ways living systems are out of equilibrium?

items.title: The long-overlooked insects that could save our crops
items.summary: Hoverflies, often mistaken for bees and wasps, pollinate three quarters of our crops. Now weâ€™re discovering we can train them to be even more efficient

items.title: 'Horrific and beautiful' whale rescue image wins photography prize
items.summary: See some of the winning entries for this year's Oceania Photo Contest, including Miesa Grobbelaar's shot of a whale, which took the top prize

items.title: Easily taxed grains were crucial to the birth of the first states
items.summary: The cultivation of wheat, barley and maize, which are easily stored and taxed, seems to have led to the emergence of large societies, rather than agriculture generally

items.title: Your brain undergoes four dramatic periods of change from age 0 to 90
items.summary: Our brain wiring seems to undergo four major turning points at ages 9, 32, 66 and 83, which could influence our capacity to learn and our risk of certain conditions

items.title: What next for friendly foes who see each other 'more than family'?
items.summary: Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz have dominated menâ€™s tennis in 2025. BBC Sport looks at the evolution of their growing rivalry â€“ and where it could go next.

items.title: A new understanding of causality could fix quantum theoryâ€™s fatal flaw
items.summary: Quantum theory fails to explain how the reality we experience emerges from the world of particles. A new take on quantum cause and effect could bridge the gap

items.title: Have we found a greener way to do deep-sea mining?
items.summary: There are widespread concerns that deep-sea mining for metals will damage fragile ecosystems. But if mining ever goes ahead, hydrogen plasma could shrink the carbon footprint of smelting the metal ores

items.title: Sperm's evolutionary origins go back before multicellular animals
items.summary: Analysis of the DNA and proteins of a range of animals has revealed that spermâ€™s molecular toolkit arose in our single-celled ancestors, perhaps more than a billion years ago

items.title: Why is climate action stalling, not ramping up as Earth gets hotter?
items.summary: As the impact of global warming becomes more obvious, you might expect countries to step up climate action and preparation, but weâ€™re seeing the opposite happen

items.title: COP30 keeps climate cooperation alive but hanging by a thread
items.summary: The 194 countries still taking part in UN climate negotiations reaffirmed the Paris Agreement following the US withdrawal, even if they agreed on little else

items.title: Extinct animals in Prehistoric Planet: Ice Age make it a must-watch
items.summary: From woolly mammoths to giant sloths, via some lesser-known ice-age beasts like 'killer koalas', the visuals in this documentary are simply astounding

items.title: Astronomers may have glimpsed evidence of the biggest stars ever seen
items.summary: The distant universe might be littered with supermassive stars between 1000 and 10,000 times the mass of the sun, which could solve a cosmic mystery about the origins of extremely large black holes

items.title: Undersea â€˜stormsâ€™ are melting the â€˜doomsdayâ€™ glacierâ€™s ice shelf
items.summary: Spinning vortices of water trapped under the Thwaites glacier ice shelf account for 20 per cent of the ice melt. Theyâ€™re expected to get worse as the world warms

items.title: Ancient tracks may record stampede of turtles disturbed by earthquake
items.summary: Around 1000 markings on a slab of rock that was once a seafloor during the Cretaceous period may have been made by sea turtle flippers and swiftly buried by an earthquake

items.title: Quantum computers need classical computing to be truly useful
items.summary: Conventional computing devices will play a crucial role in turning quantum computers into tools with real-world application

items.title: Common type of inflammatory bowel disease linked to toxic bacteria
items.summary: The discovery that a toxin made by bacteria found in dirty water might help trigger ulcerative colitis could lead to new treatments for this form of IBD

items.title: Moss spores survive and germinate after 283-day 'space walk'
items.summary: Astronauts strapped moss spores to the outside of the International Space Station for nine months - and most of them survived the challenging experience

items.title: Mouse 'midwives' help their pregnant companions give birth
items.summary: Scientists have observed mice helping each other when they encounter difficulties during birth, prompting a rethink of caregiving among rodents and other animals

items.title: Vanishing Y chromosomes could aid or worsen lung cancer outcomes
items.summary: The health impacts of men losing their Y chromosome from their cells are increasingly coming to light, with the loss playing a complicated role in the most common form of lung cancer

items.title: Weâ€™ve found an unexpected structure in the solar systemâ€™s Kuiper belt
items.summary: A newly discovered cluster of objects called the â€œinner kernelâ€ of the Kuiper belt could teach us about the early history of the solar system â€“ including the movement of Neptune

items.title: Mosquito proboscis repurposed as a fine nozzle for 3D printing
items.summary: When engineers struggled to make 3D printer nozzles narrow enough for their needs, they turned to nature and found the proboscis of a female mosquito had exactly the properties they needed

items.title: Climate heating has reached even deepest parts of the Arctic Ocean
items.summary: The depths of the Arctic Ocean have warmed more than scientists expected. New research has placed the blame on warmer water from Greenland

items.title: How a new way of thinking about fat could transform your health
items.summary: Body fat, often reviled, is actually a vital organ that contributes to your health and well-being. It is time for us to stop vilifying fat and to start exploring how we can harness its power

items.title: Is there any evidence that playing music to plants is beneficial?
items.summary: Botanist James Wong is constantly asked if he plays music to his army of plants. Time to put this notion to the test...

items.title: Brian Eno and Beatie Wolfe discuss their new spacebound album, Liminal
items.summary: Brian Eno and Beatie Wolfe's album Liminal is being transmitted into space by Nobel laureate Robert Wilson. They give Chelsea Whyte the lowdown

items.title: New Scientist recommends the Society of Wildlife Artists' annual expo
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: A fascinatingly grisly guide to replacing and repairing body parts
items.summary: Mary Roach's new book Replaceable You explores what we do when bits of our bodies break down or need switching out. It makes for a brilliant read â€“ just beware the gory details, warns Carissa Wong

items.title: Imagining a future where smart glasses allow 'AI slop' to be avoided
items.summary: In the latest in our imagined history of inventions yet to come, Future Chronicles columnist Rowan Hooper reveals how an ingenious way to avoid being swamped by AI content was invented in the late 2020s

items.title: Cars are getting bigger. This is a problem for us and for the planet
items.summary: Sport utility vehicles and other larger cars are becoming more and more common, and this is dangerous for our health in many ways. But we have ways to counter "carspreading", says Anthony Laverty

items.title: An ambitious look at quantum physics is fun â€“ but overdoes it a little
items.summary: Attempts to describe quantum physics are rarely enjoyable, but Paul Davies' zeal in Quantum 2.0 sometimes steers too close to hype, finds Karmela Padavic-Callaghan

items.title: Who finds dad jokes funniest? The answer might not astonish you
items.summary: Feedback is delighted to discover that two academics have taken a scholarly interest in dad jokes, but is unsurprised by their key finding: the people who most enjoy dad jokes are dads

items.title: Why quasicrystals shouldnâ€™t exist but are turning up in strange places
items.summary: Matter with â€œforbiddenâ€ symmetries was once thought to be confined to lab experiments, but is now being found in some of the worldâ€™s most extreme environments

items.title: Google's Gemini 3 model keeps the AI hype train going â€“ for now
items.summary: Googleâ€™s latest model reportedly beats its rivals in several benchmark tests, but issues with reliability mean concerns remain over a possible AI bubble

items.title: Quantum computers that recycle their qubits can limit errors
items.summary: To make quantum computers more efficient and reliable, some of their basic components must be constantly reused â€“ several quantum computer designs can now do just that

items.title: Physics of light and magnetism rewritten after almost two centuries
items.summary: An experiment 180 years ago first demonstrated a connection between light and electromagnetism â€“ but the link is deeper than we thought

items.title: Kissing may have evolved in an ape ancestor 21 million years ago
items.summary: Rather than being a recent cultural development, kissing may have been practised by other early humans like Neanderthals and our ape ancestors

items.title: Four-fifths of the world's population now live in urban areas
items.summary: A comprehensive UN report has found that cities and towns are home to 81 per cent of the worldâ€™s population, much more than previously thought

items.title: We can finally hear the long-hidden music of the Stone Age
items.summary: Ancient rock art was meant to be heard as well as seen and now acoustic archaeologists are bringing the sounds of prehistoric rituals to life

items.title: Mathematicians say Google's AI tools are supercharging their research
items.summary: AlphaEvolve, an AI system created by Google DeepMind, is helping mathematicians do research at a scale that was previously impossible - even if it does occasionally "cheat" to find a solution

items.title: 'It felt like God's hand on my brain' - the day England were humbled by teenager
items.summary: BBC Sport's From The Ashes series concludes with the inside story of Ashton Agar's record-breaking introduction to Test cricket as a 19-year-old batting at number 11.

items.title: Vast Bronze Age city discovered in the plains of Kazakhstan
items.summary: A major settlement in Central Asia called Semiyarka dating back to 1600 BC had houses, a big central building and even an industrial zone for producing copper and bronze

items.title: Neanderthals' hefty noses werenâ€™t well adapted to cold climates
items.summary: Neanderthals were thought to have structures inside their noses that helped them deal with the cold, but analysis of an exceptionally preserved specimen contradicts that

items.title: Parasitic ant tricks workers into killing their queen, then usurps her
items.summary: Some ants kill the queens of another species and take over their colonies, but we now know at least one species gets workers to do the dirty work for them through a kind of chemical subterfuge

items.title: The vital, overlooked role of body fat in shaping your health and mind
items.summary: The discovery that fat is a communicative organ with a role in everything from bone health to mood is forcing a rethink of how we view our bodies

items.title: Rapid melt from Antarctica could help preserve crucial ocean current
items.summary: Greenlandâ€™s melt is expected to slow the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, but research suggests a collapse of the West Antarctic ice sheet could in some cases prevent it from shutting down

items.title: The forgotten women of quantum physics
items.summary: Physics has a reputation for being dominated by men, especially a century ago, as quantum physics was just being invented â€“ but there have been so many women who helped shaped the field since its inception

items.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
items.summary: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

items.title: Finally wrangling with the complexity of female bodies benefits us all
items.summary: Medical research has long sought to gloss over the hormonal and chromosomal complications typical of female biology. But embracing this complexity could benefit everyone
